en.question: Commercial bus drivers must have a CDL if:
options: They drive a vehicle that has air brakes.
They drive a vehicle that has a gross weight rating of more than 26,000 pounds.
They drive a vehicle that is designed to carry more than fifteen (15) passengers including the driver.
en.reason:
Section: 4.0 - Transporting Passengers Safely

Bus drivers must have a commercial drivers license if they drive a vehicle designed to seat more than 16 or more persons, including the driver.

en.question: Carry-on baggage cannot be stored:
options: In the aisle.
On the seats.
Behind the seats.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2 - Loading and Trip Start

Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in a doorway or aisle. There should be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders.

en.question: Buses may carry:
options: Explosives.
Small arms ammunition labeled orm-d.
Car batteries.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.2 - Forbidden Hazardous Materials

Buses may carry small-arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and drugs.

en.question: When arriving at the destination announce:
options: The   departure time.
Both.
The location.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.4 - At Your Destination

When arriving at the destination or intermediate stops announce: (1) The location (2) Reason for stopping (3)   departure time (4) Bus Number

en.question: A disruptive passenger:
options: Should not be allowed on the bus.
Should not be discharged where it would be unsafe for them.
Is not your responsibility.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.2 - At Stops

Occasionally, you may have a drunk or disruptive rider. You must ensure this riders safety as well as that of others. Do not discharge such riders where it would be unfafe for them.

en.question: If your bus leans toward the outside on a banked curve, you are:
options: Driving at the correct speed.
Driving too slow.
Driving too fast.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.4 - Speed on Curves

Reduce speed for curves. If your bus leans toward the outside on a banked curve, you are driving too fast.

en.question: You must stop your bus between:
options: 5 to 10 feet before a railroad crossing.
20 to 25 feet before a railroad crossing.
15 and 50 feet before a railroad crossing.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.5 - Railroad-Highway Crossings Stops

Stop at RR crossings: Stop your bus between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings.

en.question: At the end of each shift you should:
options: Report any defects.
Inspect your bus.
Both.
en.reason:
Section: 4.4 - After-Trip Vehicle Inspection

Inspect your bust at the end of each shift. Riders sometimes damage safety-related parts such as handholds, seats, and windows. If you report this damage at the end of a shift, mechanics can make repairs before the bus goes out again.

en.question: The interlock system for the brake and accelerator on a transit coach may be used:
options: To replace the parking brake.
To replace the rear door emergency buzzer.
As a safety feature when the exit door is open.
en.reason:
Section: 4.6 - Use of Brake-door Interlocks

Urban mass transit coaches may have a brake and accelerator interlock system. The interlock applies the brakes and holds the throttle in idle position when the rear door is open. The interlock releases when you close the rear door. Do not use this safety feature in place of the parking brake.

en.question: Your bus is disabled. The bus, with riders aboard, may be towed or pushed to a safe place only:
options: By another bus with its 4-way flashers on.
If getting off the bus would be riskier for the riders.
If the distance is less than 1 mile.
en.reason:
Section: 4.5 - Prohibited Practices

Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle, unless getting off would be unsafe. Only tow or push the bus to the nearest safe spot to discharge passengers.

en.question: You may sometimes haul small arms ammunition, emergency shipments of drugs, or hospital supplies on a bus. The total weight of all such hazardous materials must not be greater than pounds.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.2 - Forbidden Hazardous Materials

Buses must never carry: More than 500 pounds total of allowed hazardous materials, and no more than 100 pounds of any one class.

en.question: How many seats not securely fastened to the bus are usually allowed?
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.3 - Bus Interior

The seats must be safe for riders. All seats must be securely fastened to the bus.

en.question: It is best to wear your seat belt:
options: Only when you will be driving over 35 mph.
Only if your bus holds more than 27 people.
At all times.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.5 - Use Your Seatbelt!

The driver's seat should have a seat belt. Always use it for safety.

en.question: Which of the following types of cargo can never be carried on a bus with riders?
options: Emergency hospital supplies.
Tear gas.
Emergency drug shipments.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.2 - Forbidden Hazardous Materials

Buses must never carry: Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poison, tear gas, irritating material

en.question: If a rider wants to bring a car battery or a can of gasoline aboard your bus, you should:
options: Have the rider pay a second fare.
Instruct them to sit   to an open window.
Not allow them to do it.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.2 - Forbidden Hazardous Materials

Riders sometimes board a bus with an unlabeled hazardous material. Do not allow riders to carry on common hazards such as car batteries or gasoline.

en.question: Some city transit buses may have a brake-door interlock system, this system:
options: Should be used in emergencies.
Works when the passenger exit doors are open.
Releases the brakes.
en.reason:
Section: 4.6 - Use of Brake-door Interlocks

The interlock applies the brakes and holds the throttle in idle position when the rear door is open. The interlock releases when you close the rear door.

en.question: When it is carried on a bus, hazardous material must be:
options: Packed in a yellow box.
Both.
Labeled.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.1 - Hazardous Materials

The rules require shippers to mark containers of hazardous material with the material's name, identification number, and hazard label. There are nine different four-inch, diamond-shaped hazard labels

en.question: You are driving a bus designed to allow standing. Where may a rider stand?
options: Behind the driver seat.
Behind a standee line.
No rider is allowed to stand.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.3 - Standee Line

Buses designed to allow standing must have a two-inch line on the floor or some other means of showing riders where they cannot stand. This is called the standee line. All standing riders must stay behind it.

en.question: Before driving, make sure to have the following emergency equipment: (1) fire extinguisher (2) emergency reflectors and (3):
options: Spare electrical fuses.
Two extra tires.
Extra rear-vision mirroг.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.1 - Vehicle Systems

Make sure your bus has the fire extinguisher and emergency reflectors (3 reflective triangles or at least 6 fusees or 3 liquid burning flares) required by law. The bus must also have spare electrical fuses, unless equipped with circuit breakers.

en.question: You must put a loaded bus into motion from a stopped position on a steep upgrade (4% or more). Which of these is the best technique to follow when you have a bus with a manual transmission?
options: Hold the foot brake until the clutch has been fully released.
Accelerate hard and release the clutch quickly.
Slowly release the clutch while releasing the parking brakes.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Don't roll back when you start. You may hit someone behind you. If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back.

en.question: Roof hatches:
options: Only opened during emergencies.
Are colored orange.
Can be in an open position for fresh air.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.4 - Roof Hatches

You may lock some emergency roof hatches in a partly open position for fresh air.

en.question: In general, the best braking technique to use in maintaining a safe speed when driving on a downgrade is:
options: Use the braking effect of the engine to control speed.
Using only downshifting.
Using only the parking brakes.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.6 - Speed on Downgrades

If a speed limit is posted, or there is a sign indicating "Maximum Safe Speed," never exceed the speed shown. Also, look for and heed warning signs indicating the length and steepness of the grade. You must use the braking effect of the engine as the principal way of controlling your speed on downgrades.

en.question: Which of these is the best general rule for night driving?
options: Drive slightly slower than the other traffic.
Make sure your headlights are clean and working.
Drive slightly faster than the other traffic.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.4 - Vehicle Factors

Night driving can be more dangerous if you have problems with your headlights. Dirty headlights may give only half the light they should. This cuts down your ability to see, and makes it harder for others to see you. Make sure your lights are clean and working.

en.question: Secure baggage and freight in ways that avoid damage and:
options: Allow riders to exit quickly.
Allow baggage to be found quickly.
Allow the driver to move freely and easily.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2 - Loading and Trip Start

Secure baggage and freight in ways that avoid damage and: (1) Allow the driver to move freely and easily (2) Allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency (3) Protect riders from injury if carry-ons fall or shift.

en.question: How are buses to handle most railroad grade crossings?
options: Turn the vehicle flashers on before crossing.
Tap the electric horn before crossing.
Stop between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.5 - Railroad-highway Crossing/Stops

Stop your bus between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings.

en.question: Which of these is a good rule for backing a straight bus?
options: None of these.
Use voice signals to communicate with a helper.
Back toward the side opposite to the driver.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

When you have to back, here are a few simple safety rules: Back and turn toward the driver's side whenever possible. Use a helper when you can. There are blind spots you can't see. That's why a helper is important. The helper should stand near the back of your vehicle where you can see the helper. Before you begin backing, work out a set of hand signals that you both understand. Agree on a signal for "stop."

en.question: Which of these forms of signaling is not recommended?
options: Signaling to others that it is safe to pass your bus.
Signaling to others that you will change lanes.
Using four-way flashers to warn of danger ahead.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Some drivers try to help out others by signaling when it is safe to pass. You should not do this. You could cause an accident. You could be blamed and it could cost you many thousands of dollars.

en.question: You should stop at least the draw of the bridge. feet before
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.6 - Drawbridges

Stop at drawbridges that do not have a signal light or traffic control attendant. Stop at least 50 feet before the draw of the bridge. Look to make sure the draw is completely closed before crossing.

en.question: In a pressurized cooling system, coolant level should be checked:
options: Every 90 days.
Only by a mechanic.
Neither
en.reason:
Section: 2.14.1 - Vehicle Checks

Before starting out, make sure the engine cooling system has enough water and antifreeze according to the engine manufacturer's directions. Visually check level of coolant and add more coolant if necessary.

en.question: You need to evacuate your bus in an emergency, passengers should be directed to a safe place no less than feet from the bus.
en.reason:
Section: 10.3.2 - Evacuation Procedures

Some tips to determine a safe place: A safe place will be at least 100 feet off the road in the direction of oncoming traffic.

en.question: If your bus has an emergency exit door, it must:
options: Have a red electric door light turned on at all times.
both
Be secured when operating the bus.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.3 - Bus Interior

Never drive with an open emergency exit door or window.

en.question: Which of the following must be closed while the bus is in motion?
options: Windows.
Emergency windows.
Roof vents.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.3 - Bus Interior

Never drive with an open emergency exit door or window.

en.question: The standee line is?
options: A two-inch line on the floor to the rear of the driver's seat.
A line two feet from the rear exit.
There is no such thing on a bus.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.3 - Standee Line

Buses designed to allow standing must have a two-inch line on the floor or some other means of showing riders where they cannot stand. This is called the standee line.

en.question: Charter drivers should:
options: Mention rules.
Explain rules
Both.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.1 - Passenger Supervision

Many charter and intercity carriers have passenger comfort and safety rules. Mention rules about smoking, drinking, or use of radio and tape players at the start of the trip. Explaining the rules at the start will help to avoid trouble later on.

en.question: At drawbridges with no signal you must stop at least?
options: 20 to 25 feet before the draw of the bridge.
15 to 20 feet before the draw of the bridge.
50 feet before the draw of the bridge.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.6 - Drawbridges

Stop at drawbridges that do not have a signal light or traffic control attendant. Stop at least 50 feet before the draw of the bridge.

en.question: Prohibited practices on the bus include?
options: All of these
Talking with riders while driving.
Fueling your bus with riders on board.
en.reason:
Section: 4.5 - Prohibited Practices

Avoid fueling your bus with riders on board unless absolutely necessary. Never refuel in a closed building with riders on board. Do not talk with riders, or engage in any other distracting activity, while driving.

en.question: Buses may have recapped or re-grooved tires:
options: Anywhere except on the front wheels.
On any or all the wheels.
Only on the outside wheel of dual wheels.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.1 - Vehicle Systems

Make sure these things are in good working order before driving: Tires (front wheels must not have recapped or re-grooved tires).

en.question: When you inspect your bus, you must make sure that?
options: Both.
Emergency exit handles are secure.
Rider signaling devices are working.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.3 - Bus Interior

The following parts of your bus must be in safe working condition: Signaling devices, including the restroom emergency buzzer, if the bus has a restroom. Emergency exit handles.

en.question: If you have riders aboard, you must never fuel your bus:
options: In a closed building.
With a higher grade of fuel.
Without a static chain.
en.reason:
Section: 4.5 - Prohibited Practices

Avoid fueling your bus with riders on board unless absolutely necessary. Never refuel in a closed building with riders on board.

en.question: A bus may carry baggage or freight only if it is secured so that:
options: Both
Allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency
The driver can move freely and easily.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2 - Loading and Trip Start

Secure baggage and freight in ways that avoid damage and: (1) Allow the driver to move freely and easily. (2) Allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency. (3) Protect riders from injury if carry-ons fall or shift.

en.question: You must not permit standing riders?
options: In front of the standee line.
Within two feet of any window.
Between the wheel wells.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.3 - Standee Line

Buses designed to allow standing must have a two-inch line on the floor or some other means of showing riders where they cannot stand. This is called the standee line.

en.question: Due to the extreme size of a bus, the driver must watch for?
options: Clearance your bus needs.
Poles and wires
Both.
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.3 - Common Accidents

School and mass transit buses sometimes scrape off mirrors or hit passing vehicles when pulling out from a bus stop. Remember the clearance your bus needs, and watch for poles and tree limbs at stops.

en.question: The interlock releases when you:
options: Release parking brake.
Close the rear door.
Close the front door.
en.reason:
Section: 4.6 - Use of Brake-door Interlocks

The interlock releases when you close the rear door.

en.question: Which of the following lists the three types of emergency equipment you must have on your bus?
options: Hydraulic jack, fire extinguisher, signal flares.
Repair kit, spare electric fuses, and fire extinguisher.
Fire extinguisher, spare electrical fuses, and emergency reflectors.
en.reason:
Section: 4.1.1 - Vehicle Systems

Make sure your bus has the fire extinguisher and emergency reflectors (3 reflective triangles or at least 6 fusees or 3 liquid burning flares) required by law. The bus must also have spare electrical fuses, unless equipped with circuit breakers.

en.question: You do not have to stop, but slow down at?
options: Streetcar crossing.
When a policeman or flagman is directing traffic.
Both
en.reason:
Section: 4.3.5 - Railroad-highway Crossing/Stops

You do not have to stop, but must slow down and carefully check for other vehicles: (1): At streetcar crossings. (2): Where a policeman or flagman is directing traffic.

en.question: Do not transport any hazardous material
options: Unless you secured it yourself.
Unless you are sure the rules allow it.
Unless it looks safe.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.1 - Hazardous Materials

Do not transport any hazardous material unless you are sure the rules allow it.

en.question: If you increase your speed from 20 to 60 mph (original speed times 3), how much more braking distance is required at 60 mph than at 20 mph?
options: 3 x 3 or 9 times.
3 x 4 or 12 times.
3 x 2 or 6 times.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The faster you drive, the greater the impact or striking power of your vehicle. When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph the impact is 4 times greater. The braking distance is also 4 times longer. Triple the speed from 20 to 60 mph and the impact and braking distance is 9 times greater.

en.question: When driving at more than 40 mph, what is the safe minimum following distance for ideal daytime conditions?
options: Four seconds.
five seconds.
One second for every 10 feet of vehicle length (rounded upward to the nearest 10 feet).
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.1 - Space Ahead

If you are driving a 40-foot truck and only counted up to 2 seconds, you're too close. Drop back a little and count again until you have 4 seconds of following distance (or 5 seconds, if you're going over 40 mph).

en.question: When arriving at the destination, or intermediate stops, you should announce: The location, reason for stopping, next departure time, and?
options: Company contact information.
Bus number.
Your full name and driver ID.
en.reason:
Section: 4.2.4 - At Your Destination

When arriving at the destination or intermediate stops announce: (1) The location. (2) Reason for stopping. (3) Next departure time (4) Bus number.

en.question: The proper time to cancel your turn signal for a lane change or turn is?
options: Just before starting the maneuver.
About halfway through the maneuver.
When the maneuver is complete.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Signal continuously. You need both hands on the wheel to turn safely. Don't cancel the signal until you have completed the turn.

pt.question: Motoristas de ônibus comerciais devem ter CDL se:
options: Eles dirigem um veículo que tem freios a ar.
Eles dirigem um veículo que tem um peso bruto de mais de 26.000 libras.
Eles dirigem um veículo projetado para transportar mais de 15 (quinze) passageiros, incluindo o motorista.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.0 - Transporte de passageiros com segurança

Os motoristas de ônibus devem ter carteira de motorista comercial se dirigirem veículo projetado para acomodar mais de 16 ou mais pessoas, incluindo o motorista.

pt.question: A bagagem de mão não pode ser armazenada:
options: No corredor.
Nos assentos.
Atrás dos assentos.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2 - Início do carregamento e da viagem

Não permita que os passageiros deixem a bagagem de mão em uma porta ou corredor. Não deve haver nada no corredor que possa tropeçar em outros pilotos.

pt.question: Os autocarros podem transportar:
options: Explosivos
Munições de armas pequenas rotuladas orm-d.
Baterias de carro.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.2 - Materiais Perigosos Proibidos

Os ônibus podem transportar munições de armas pequenas rotuladas como ORM-D, suprimentos hospitalares de emergência e drogas.

pt.question: Ao chegar ao destino anuncie:
options: A hora da partida.
Os dois.
A localização.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.4 - No seu destino

Ao chegar ao destino ou paradas intermediárias anuncie: (1) A localização (2) Reason da parada (3)     hora de partida (4) Número do ônibus

pt.question: Um passageiro perturbador:
options: Não deve ser permitido entrar no ônibus.
Não devem ser descarregados onde seria inseguro para eles.
Não é responsabilidade sua.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.3.2 - Em Stops

Ocasionalmente, você pode ter um motociclista bêbado ou perturbador. É preciso garantir a segurança deste motociclista, assim como a dos demais. Não dispense tais pilotos onde seria desagradável para eles.

pt.question: Se o seu ônibus se inclina para o exterior em uma curva inclinada, você está:
options: Dirigir na velocidade correta.
Dirigir muito devagar.
Dirigir rápido demais.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.3.4 - Velocidade em curvas

Reduza a velocidade para curvas. Se o seu ônibus se inclina para o lado de fora em uma curva inclinada, você está dirigindo muito rápido.

pt.question: Você deve parar seu ônibus entre:
options: 5 a 10 pés antes de uma travessia ferroviária.
20 a 25 pés antes de uma travessia ferroviária.
15 e 50 pés antes de uma travessia ferroviária.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.3.5 - Travessias Ferrovia-Rodovia Paragens

Pare nos cruzamentos RR: Pare seu ônibus entre 15 e 50 pés antes das travessias ferroviárias.

pt.question: No final de cada turno você deve:
options: Denuncie quaisquer defeitos.
Inspecione seu ônibus.
Os dois.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.4 - Inspeção Veicular Pós-Viagem

Inspecione seu busto no final de cada turno. Os pilotos às vezes danificam peças relacionadas à segurança, como apoios de mão, bancos e janelas. Se você relatar esse dano no final de um turno, os mecânicos podem fazer reparos antes que o ônibus saia novamente.

pt.question: Pode ser utilizado o sistema de bloqueio do travão e do acelerador de um autocarro de trânsito:
options: Para substituir o freio de estacionamento.
Para substituir a campainha de emergência da porta traseira.
Como um recurso de segurança quando a porta de saída está aberta.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.6 - Uso de Intertravamentos de Porta de Freio

Os ônibus de transporte coletivo urbano podem ter um sistema de intertravamento de freio e acelerador. O intertravamento aciona os freios e mantém o acelerador em marcha lenta quando a porta traseira está aberta. O intertravamento se solta quando você fecha a porta traseira. Não use este recurso de segurança no lugar do freio de estacionamento.

pt.question: Seu ônibus está desativado. O autocarro, com passageiros a bordo, só pode ser rebocado ou empurrado para um local seguro:
options: Por outro ônibus com seus pisca-piscas de 4 vias ligados.
Se descer do ônibus seria mais arriscado para os passageiros.
Se a distância for inferior a 1 milha.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.5 - Práticas Proibidas

Não reboque ou empurre um ônibus com deficientes com passageiros a bordo do veículo, a menos que descer seja inseguro. Apenas reboque ou empurre o ônibus para o local seguro mais próximo para descarregar os passageiros.

pt.question: Às vezes, você pode transportar munição de armas pequenas, remessas emergenciais de medicamentos ou suprimentos hospitalares em um ônibus. O peso total de todos esses materiais perigosos não deve ser superior a libras.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.2 - Materiais Perigosos Proibidos

Os ônibus nunca devem transportar: Mais de 500 libras no total de materiais perigosos permitidos, e não mais de 100 libras de qualquer classe.

pt.question: Quantos assentos não fixados com segurança ao ônibus são geralmente permitidos?
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.1.3 - Interior do ônibus

Os assentos devem ser seguros para os passageiros. Todos os assentos devem ser fixados de forma segura ao ônibus.

pt.question: É melhor usar o cinto de segurança:
options: Somente quando você estiver dirigindo mais de 35 mph.
Só se o seu ônibus comportar mais de 27 pessoas.
Em todos os momentos.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.1.5 - Use o cinto de segurança!

O banco do motorista deve ter cinto de segurança. Use-o sempre por segurança.

pt.question: Qual dos seguintes tipos de carga nunca pode ser transportado em um ônibus com passageiros?
options: Material hospitalar de emergência
Gás lacrimogêneo
Remessas emergenciais de medicamentos
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.2 - Materiais perigosos proibidos

Os ônibus nunca devem transportar: Divisão 2.3 gás venenoso, líquido Classe 6 veneno, gás lacrimogêneo, material irritante

pt.question: Se um motociclista quiser trazer uma bateria de carro ou uma lata de gasolina a bordo do seu ônibus, você deve:
options: Peça ao motociclista que pague uma segunda tarifa.
Instrua-os a sentar-se em uma janela aberta.
Não permita que o façam.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.2 - Materiais Perigosos Proibidos

Os passageiros às vezes embarcam em um ônibus com um material perigoso não identificado. Não permita que os pilotos carreguem perigos comuns, como baterias de carros ou gasolina.

pt.question: Alguns ônibus de trânsito urbano podem ter um sistema de intertravamento de porta de freio, este sistema:
options: Deve ser usado em emergências.
Funciona quando as portas de saída do passageiro estão abertas.
Solta o freio.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.6 - Uso de intertravamentos de porta de freio

O intertravamento aplica os freios e mantém o acelerador em posição de marcha lenta quando a porta traseira está aberta. O intertravamento se solta quando você fecha a porta traseira.

pt.question: Quando é transportado num autocarro, as matérias perigosas devem ser:
options: Embalado em uma caixa amarela.
Os dois.
Rotulado.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.1 - Materiais Perigosos

As regras exigem que os expedidores marquem os contêineres de materiais perigosos com o nome do material, número de identificação e etiqueta de perigo. Existem nove diferentes etiquetas de perigo de quatro polegadas em forma de diamante

pt.question: Você está dirigindo um ônibus projetado para permitir ficar em pé. Onde pode estar um motociclista?
options: Atrás do banco do motorista.
Atrás de uma linha de standee.
Nenhum ciclista pode ficar em pé.
pt.reason:
Seção: 4.2.3 - Linha Standee

Os ônibus projetados para permitir a permanência em pé devem ter uma linha de duas polegadas no chão ou algum outro meio de mostrar aos passageiros onde eles não podem ficar em pé. Isso é chamado de linha standee. Todos os pilotos em pé devem ficar atrás dele.

pt.question: Antes de conduzir, certifique-se de ter os seguintes equipamentos de emergência: (1) extintor de incêndio (2) refletores de emergência e (3):
options: Fusíveis elétricos sobressalentes.
Dois pneus a mais.
Mirro de visão traseira extra.
